natural problem:
Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
natural solution: Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.

Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: int
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "lcm (lcm h t) u = 1"
shows  "listsum [100*h + 10*t + u |h. h \<in> {1..100}, t. t \<in> {1..100}, u. u \<in> {1..100}] = 757"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: int
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "lcm (lcm h t) u = 1"
shows  "listsum [100*h + 10*t + u |h. h \<in> {1..100}, t. t \<in> {1..100}, u. u \<in> {1..100}] = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all three-digit numbers $100h + 10t + u$ where $h$, $t$, and $u$ are positive integers from 1 to 100 and the lowest common multiple of $h$, $t$, and $u$ is 1. The final answer is 757.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod h = 0 \<or> n mod t = 0 \<or> n mod u = 0"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod h = 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod t \<noteq> 0 \<and> n mod u \<noteq> 0"
and h5 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod t = 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod h \<noteq> 0 \<and> n mod u \<noteq> 0"
and h6 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod u = 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod h \<noteq> 0 \<and> n mod t \<noteq> 0"
shows  "(\<Sum> h \<leftarrow> [1..100]. \<Sum> t \<leftarrow> [1..10]. \<Sum> u \<leftarrow> [1..10]. if h3 and h4 and h5 and h6 then 100*h + 10*t + u else 0) = 757"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod h = 0 \<or> n mod t = 0 \<or> n mod u = 0"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod h = 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod t \<noteq> 0 \<and> n mod u \<noteq> 0"
and h5 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod t = 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod h \<noteq> 0 \<and> n mod u \<noteq> 0"
and h6 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod u = 0 \<longrightarrow> n mod h \<noteq> 0 \<and> n mod t \<noteq> 0"
shows  "(\<Sum> h \<leftarrow> [1..100]. \<Sum> t \<leftarrow> [1..10]. \<Sum> u \<leftarrow> [1..10]. if h3 and h4 and h5 and h6 then 100*h + 10*t + u else 0) = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: For positive integers h, t, and u, if every integer greater than 0 is divisible by either h, t, or u, but no integer greater than 0 is divisible by more than one of h, t, or u, what is the sum of 100*h + 10*t + u for all combinations of h from 1 to 100, t from 1 to 10, and u from 1 to 10? The final answer is 757.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. (n mod h = 0 \<or> n mod t = 1 \<or> n mod u = 2) \<and> (n mod h \<noteq> 0 \<or> n mod t \<noteq> 1 \<or> n mod u \<noteq> 2)"
shows  "(\<Sum> h \<leftarrow> [1..<100]. \<Sum> t \<leftarrow> [1..<10]. \<Sum> u \<leftarrow> [1..<10]. if h0 \<and> h1 \<and> h2 \<and> h3 then 100*h + 10*t + u else 0) = 757"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. (n mod h = 0 \<or> n mod t = 1 \<or> n mod u = 2) \<and> (n mod h \<noteq> 0 \<or> n mod t \<noteq> 1 \<or> n mod u \<noteq> 2)"
shows  "(\<Sum> h \<leftarrow> [1..<100]. \<Sum> t \<leftarrow> [1..<10]. \<Sum> u \<leftarrow> [1..<10]. if h0 \<and> h1 \<and> h2 \<and> h3 then 100*h + 10*t + u else 0) = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: For each number $n$, it is either divisible by a positive number $h$, leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by a positive number $t$, or leaves a remainder of 2 when divided by a positive number $u$. However, it does not satisfy all three conditions simultaneously. Find the sum of $100h + 10t + u$ for all $h$ between 1 and 99, for all $t$ between 1 and 9, and for all $u$ between 1 and 9 that satisfy the given conditions. The sum is equal to 757.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "paintable h t u \<longleftrightarrow> (\<forall>n. (\<exists>i. n = i * h) \<or> (\<exists>j. n = j * t) \<or> (\<exists>k. n = k * u) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!i. n = i * h) \<and> (\<exists>!j. n = j * t) \<and> (\<exists>!k. n = k * u))"
shows  "(\<Sum>h\<le>9. \<Sum>t\<le>9. \<Sum>u\<le>9. if paintable h t u then 100*h + 10*t + u else 0) = 757"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "paintable h t u \<longleftrightarrow> (\<forall>n. (\<exists>i. n = i * h) \<or> (\<exists>j. n = j * t) \<or> (\<exists>k. n = k * u) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!i. n = i * h) \<and> (\<exists>!j. n = j * t) \<and> (\<exists>!k. n = k * u))"
shows  "(\<Sum>h\<le>9. \<Sum>t\<le>9. \<Sum>u\<le>9. if paintable h t u then 100*h + 10*t + u else 0) = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
Suppose we have three positive integers $h$, $t$ and $u$. A number $n$ is called paintable if it can be written as the product of $h$, $t$ or $u$ with some integer in one and only one way. 

Find the sum of the numbers $100h+10t+u$ for all paintable combinations of $h$, $t$ and $u$ where $h$, $t$ and $u$ are each less than or equal to 9. 

The final answer is 757.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes h t u :: nat and paintable :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> h t u. h > 0 \<and> t > 0 \<and> u > 0 \<and> gcd h t = 1 \<and> gcd h u = 1 \<and> gcd t u = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> h t u. paintable (100*h + 10*t + u) = h + t + u"
shows  "sum paintable {h,t,u} = 757"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes h t u :: nat and paintable :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> h t u. h > 0 \<and> t > 0 \<and> u > 0 \<and> gcd h t = 1 \<and> gcd h u = 1 \<and> gcd t u = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> h t u. paintable (100*h + 10*t + u) = h + t + u"
shows  "sum paintable {h,t,u} = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Assume that $h$, $t$, and $u$ are positive integers with greatest common divisor of each pair equal to 1. A function `paintable` is defined such that `paintable` of any number formed by concatenating $h$, $t$, and $u$ as hundreds, tens, and units digit respectively is equal to the sum of $h$, $t$, and $u$. Find the sum of `paintable` values of $h$, $t$, and $u$. The final answer is 757.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "gcd (gcd h t) u = 1"
and h1 : "h \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "t \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "u \<ge> 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. (\<exists> i j k. n = i*h + j*t + k*u) \<longrightarrow> (n mod h = 1 \<or> n mod t = 2 \<or> n mod u = 3)"
shows  " (\<Sum>h=1..9. \<Sum>t=1..9. \<Sum>u=1..9. if h0 and h1 and h2 then 100*h + 10*t + u else 0) = 757"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "gcd (gcd h t) u = 1"
and h1 : "h \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "t \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "u \<ge> 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. (\<exists> i j k. n = i*h + j*t + k*u) \<longrightarrow> (n mod h = 1 \<or> n mod t = 2 \<or> n mod u = 3)"
shows  " (\<Sum>h=1..9. \<Sum>t=1..9. \<Sum>u=1..9. if h0 and h1 and h2 then 100*h + 10*t + u else 0) = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider three natural numbers h, t, and u each at least 1, such that the greatest common divisor of h, t, and u is 1. If for all natural numbers n, there exist i, j, k such that n equals i*h + j*t + k*u, then n mod h equals 1 or n mod t equals 2 or n mod u equals 3. Compute the sum of all combinations of h, t, and u from 1 to 9 where the condition holds. Each combination is represented by the number 100*h + 10*t + u. The final answer is 757.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "gcd h t u = 1"
and h1 : "lcm (lcm h t) u = 100"
and h2 : "h > 0 \<and> t > 0 \<and> u > 0"
shows  "(\<Sum> h \<le> 10, t \<le> 10, u \<le> 10. 100*h + 10*t + u) = 757"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.

 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "gcd h t u = 1"
and h1 : "lcm (lcm h t) u = 100"
and h2 : "h > 0 \<and> t > 0 \<and> u > 0"
shows  "(\<Sum> h \<le> 10, t \<le> 10, u \<le> 10. 100*h + 10*t + u) = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the sum of all three-digit numbers, where each digit is between 1 and 10, the greatest common divisor of the digits is 1, and the least common multiple of the digits is 100. The final sum is 757.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "lcm (lcm h t) u = h * t * u"
and h1 : "h > 0"
and h2 : "t > 0"
and h3 : "u > 0"
shows  "\<Sum> {100*h + 10*t + u | h t u. h > 0 \<and> t > 0 \<and> u > 0 \<and> lcm (lcm h t) u = h * t * u} = 757"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: nat
assumes h0 : "lcm (lcm h t) u = h * t * u"
and h1 : "h > 0"
and h2 : "t > 0"
and h3 : "u > 0"
shows  "\<Sum> {100*h + 10*t + u | h t u. h > 0 \<and> t > 0 \<and> u > 0 \<and> lcm (lcm h t) u = h * t * u} = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: "Find the sum of all three-digit numbers, $100h + 10t + u$, where $h, t,$ and $u$ are positive and the least common multiple of $h, t,$ and $u$ equals the product of $h, t,$ and $u$. The final sum is 757."

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: nat and paintable :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> h t u. gcd h (gcd t u) = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> h t u. h > 0 \<and> t > 0 \<and> u > 0 \<and> 100 * h + 10 * t + u is paintable"
shows  "sum paintable {n. n \<in> {1..1000}} = 757"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: nat and paintable :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> h t u. gcd h (gcd t u) = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> h t u. h > 0 \<and> t > 0 \<and> u > 0 \<and> 100 * h + 10 * t + u is paintable"
shows  "sum paintable {n. n \<in> {1..1000}} = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Assume that a natural number $n$ is "paintable" if it is of the form $100h + 10t + u$, where $h$, $t$, and $u$ are natural numbers greater than 0, and the greatest common divisor of $h$, $t$ and $u$ is 1. What is the sum of all paintable numbers between 1 and 1000? The final answer is 757.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes h t u :: int
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n mod h = 1 \<or> n mod t = 2 \<or> n mod u = 3"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> x. 100 * h + 10 * t + u) {x. x mod h = 1 \<and> x mod t = 2 \<and> x mod u = 3} = 757"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Harold, Tanya, and Ulysses paint a very long picket fence.
Harold starts with the first picket and paints every $h$ th picket;
Tanya starts with the second picket and paints every $t$ th picket; and
Ulysses starts with the third picket and paints every $u$ th picket.
Call the positive integer $100h+10t+u$ paintable when the triple $(h,t,u)$ of positive integers results in every picket being painted exactly once. Find the sum of all the paintable integers.
 The final Answer is 757
 ### Proof
 Note that it is impossible for any of $h,t,u$ to be $1$, since then each picket will have been painted one time, and then some will be painted more than once. $h$ cannot be $2$, or that will result in painting the third picket twice.
 If $h=3$, then $t$ may not equal anything not divisible by $3$, and the same for $u$.
 Now for fourth and fifth pickets to be painted, $t$ and $u$ must be $3$ as well. This configuration works, so $333$ is paintable. If $h$ is $4$, then $t$ must be even. The same for $u$, except that it can't be $2 \mod 4$.
 Thus $u$ is $0 \mod 4$ and $t$ is $2 \mod 4$. Since this is all $\mod 4$, $t$ must be $2$ and $u$ must be $4$, in order for $5,6$ to be paint-able.
 Thus $424$ is paintable. $h$ cannot be greater than $5$, since if that were the case then the answer would be greater than $999$, which would be impossible for the AIME.
 Thus the sum of all paintable numbers is $\boxed{757}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes h t u :: int
assumes h0 : "h > 0"
and h1 : "t > 0"
and h2 : "u > 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n mod h = 1 \<or> n mod t = 2 \<or> n mod u = 3"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> x. 100 * h + 10 * t + u) {x. x mod h = 1 \<and> x mod t = 2 \<and> x mod u = 3} = 757"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: For positive integers h, t, and u, let's consider a set of numbers which when divided by h leave a remainder of 1, by t leave a remainder of 2, and by u leave a remainder of 3. What is the sum of the numbers in this set, each multiplied by 100h + 10t + u? The final answer is 757.
